div.l: Tille we be rotend can we not be ripe
We hoppyn alwey while the world wolle pipe
For in oure wille there stikketh evir a nayle
To haue an hore hede and a grene taile
As hath a leke for thowe oure myght be gone
Oure wille desireth fully evir in one
For whan we may noght do / than wolle we speken
Yet in oure colde Aysshen olde fire is rekyn
Foure gledes haue we whiche I shalle deuyse
Avauntynge lyynge angre and couetsisecouesecouetise
This foure sparkles longeth vnto elde
Oure olde lymys mowe we not be welde
But wille shalle not faille that is soth
And yet haue I alwey a coltis toth
As many a yere as it is passed henne
Syn that my tap of lyff began to renne
For sickirly whan I was borne anone
Deth drowe the tappe of lyff and let hyt gone
And evir sith hath so the tappe ronne
Tille that almoste al empty is the tonne
The streme of lyff nowe dropeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge may welle rynge and chymbe
Of wrechednes that past is fulle yore
With olde folke saue dotage is nomore
Whan that oure hoste had herde this sermonynge
He gan to speke as lordely as a kynge
And seyde whate amounteth al this witt
Whate shul we speke alday of holy wrytt
The deuyl made a reve for to preche
Or of a sowter a shipmaÌ„n or a leche
Sey forth thy tale and tary not the tyme
Lo depford hit is halfe wey to pryme
Lo grenewiche that many a shrewe is ynne
Hit were alle tyme thy tale for to begynne
